title: Tip to a 'crime-fighting' Facebook page leads to a woman's arrest in 15-year-old cold-case murder
text:
A North Carolina woman has been arrested in the cold-case murder of her sister-in-law and one-time roommate, whose remains were discovered last week on the suspect's property thanks to a tip sent to an amateur crime-fighting Facebook page.

Remains believed to be Deborah Deans, a 29-year-old mother-of-four, were recovered on Thursday in a shallow grave behind a Spring Hope home belonging to 49-year-old Kimberly Hancock.

Nash County Sheriff Keith Stone says the department received a tip about the remains last week and carried out a search warrant at the home Thursday.

Scroll down for video

Kimberly Hancock, 49 (left), has been charged with first-degree murder in the 2004 killing of her sister-in-law, 29-year-old mom-of-four Deborah Deans (right)

Police acting on a tip emailed to a Facebook group went to Hancock's home in Spring Hope, North Carolina, and found remains believed to be Deans in a shallow grave

The detailed tip was initially communicated to the Facebook group 'Fighting Crime News and Who's Wanted,' which boasts 63,000 followers, according to WNCN.

The unnamed informant reached out to the administrator of the page in response to a flier that she posted on October 20 raising awareness of Deans' missing person cold case from 2004.

The administrator passed the tip along to the authorities, who then obtained a search warrant and descended on Hancock's property in the 1400 block of Wiley Road in Spring Hope, reported WRAL.

Sheriff Stone said the the tip was 'consistent with the description of the wrapping and how the body was buried.'

An autopsy will determine the identity but there was 'a strong possibility' the remains belong to Deans, who was last seen at Hancock's home in January 2004.

This flier shared on he Facebook group 'Fighting Crime News and Who's Wanted' on October 20 prompted a person familiar with the case to come forward

Deans' mother reported her missing in April of that year, saying she had not heard from her since January, when Deans was released from prison after serving a sentence for passing bad checks.

When interviewed by police at the time, Hancock told them that she and her sister-in-law had an argument, after which Deans called someone to pick her up and took off, leaving behind two of her children, an infant and a five-year-old.

Deans' two other children were in the care of their grandmother at the time.

Elaine Blevins, Dean's mother, told The Rocky Mount Telegram in 2004 that her daughter would not have walked out on her children, or severed communication with her family and friends.

The following year, Hancock was found guilty of cashing Deans' child support checks.

Hancock made her initial court appearance on Friday and was ordered jailed without bail

Hancock made her initial court appearance on Friday and was ordered held without bond in Deans' murder.

ABC11 reported that in 1989, Hancock, then known as Kimberly Kay Privette, was charged with manslaughter for shooting her father in the face as he slept on the couch, but was given a suspended sentence after arguing that the victim had been abusive toward her.

Her criminal record includes additional convictions on drug charges and DWI.
description: Kimberly Hancock, 49, has been charged with first-degree murder in the 2004 killing of her sister-in-law, mom-of-four Deborah Deans. Remains believed to be those of Deans were found last week.
